I have a hard time judging how I feel about this game, but I'd feel wrong leaving a bad recommendation (because it was fun for a while) so although this review is largely critical, I'm still leaving a positive review.  Maybe my expectations are too high for a small indie dev, but this game is SO close to being my favorite bullet heaven game because it has most of what I want in it.

At first, this game felt really fun, in the same "bullet heaven" genre of games that's been recently popular + [i]Diablo[/i]-style loot/drops.  In the beginning progression felt fun, and loot drops felt fun, but after ~28 hours of playtime, unlocking the rift/portal feature, and getting to just floor 13, I think I'm done, at least for now.

Here are the things that caused me to lose interest:

- Some enemy design is downright obnoxious/stupid (the damn crows (AWFUL - too fast, too tanky, too unpredictable with movement especially when they veer towards you), the ice skeletons that release unpredictable projectiles on death, the wasps, whose projectile color is the same as every enemy that spawns rendering them REALLY hard to see and ESPECIALLY the elites that mark you for death and if you don't kill them in 30 seconds they instantly kill you even if they don't touch you.

- At first progression felt okay, but in later floors it feels a lot like "hey your build is feeling pretty strong now, you beat the floor!  Now try this next floor that's ball-stompingly hard and grind it until you can beat it so you can do the same thing on the next floor :D" It could use some smoothing out.

- Crafting needs more QoL.  Why do I have to pull stuff from storage and THEN bring it to the NPC?  If we're in the hub why can't the UI for the NPC just allow me to pull materials from storage to use?

- Boring stats on gear aside from legendaries.  Legendaries have fun ability-altering stats, everything else is +1% crit chance, +3 Strength, +2% HP recovery, etc.  Also non-legendary gear seems to come in two flavors: one with a star on it (meaning at least one stat is its max roll for that stat on that piece), then some rares are marked as "empowered" or something like that in the text, I have yet to figure out what difference it makes, it is not explained.

- In later stages and with tons of enemies on the screen, the transparency options that exist are *not* enough for the screen to be readable.  We really need options to make our own abilities like maybe 10% opaque, then options to make enemy projectiles more opaque, or all a single obvious color, like red or something.  There's SO much visual noise, even with the existing settings being used.

- The blacksmith banging away constantly is a minor complaint but its so annoying when you're trying to think.  Please give  us an option to mute him and the alchemist noise too.

- Upgrading gear could be a lot more fun if it was like, upgrade it to level 5 then CHOOSE from 5 potential upgrades, rather than at level 5 here's this random and probably useless stat, but you can reset this item's level 5 times to get different (and probably useless stats).  And maybe you can reset each item once/twice or something. Then at level 10 choose from 5 more, etc.  Just a thought.

I will say each update to this game keeps making it better and better so I'll probably re-visit after the next update.  Please do not give up on it, you do have a fun game here, it just needs some more polishing :D

[b]OVERALL RATING:[/b] 7/10

Well, this is Vampire Survivors with the Diablo III item system, graphics stolen from Darkest Dungeon and sound effects stolen from Halls of Torment. Does this game add anything new to the genre? I fear not. 
It is, however, very solid. The graphic style my be stolen but it's very polished and crisp. I applaud the fact that they didn't use early 90s pixel graphics and called it retro once more, a trend that has become annoying (and I am saying this is somoene that DOES value gameplay over graphics).

It comes across a bit dull if you played more games of this genre. You'll get showered in items and the grey quality is obsolete as soon as the first time you are allowed to equip them. Blue rarity is outdated after your second run. Most items only scale a big selection of stat-tweaking, so that isn't exciting either. Only legendary items do have special affixes and as far as I can tell they tweak the existing skills, haven't seen one yet that actually has a special ability on it's own. 

Ther [i]are[/i] various ways to enhance, transmute and pimp items which I can't use yet because the resources for that (like gems) haven't dropped yet but I since everything follows Diablo to the point I guess that won't hold any surprises, too. 

Non-itame meta progression is done via gold and is more or less limited to a few stat increases and upping the chance of multi-levelup for the various skills. The latter might be the only thing about this game that I haven't seen before and it isn't much. 

I still recommend this game as of now beause I can't give a neutral review and the game will still be entertaining enough for anybody new to this genre. But if you have about a dozen games like this in your library, don't bother unless you are a collector.

Tower of Babel: Survivors of Chaos wastes no time pulling you into its dark-fantasy premise: a lone hero ascends a cursed tower that grows more hostile the higher you climb, a place where monsters swarm in increasing numbers and every floor becomes a test of adaptability and survival. The game puts its focus squarely on fast, kinetic hack-and-slash action, presenting each run as a condensed gauntlet of escalating danger. Whether you choose a bruising Warrior, a spell-flinging Wizard, or a close-quarters Brawler, the early moments set the pace — you are outnumbered, constantly pressured, and pushed to rely on quick reflexes as much as your character build. The premise is simple, but the execution thrives on intensity and momentum, creating a loop that feels immediately satisfying even before deeper systems begin to unfold.

At the heart of the game is a blend of roguelite randomness and action-RPG progression, and this hybrid structure gives Tower of Babel its personality. Every monster you defeat spills gold, souls, or loot; each item carries randomized affixes that nudge your character toward different builds. A single run can transform from a straightforward melee slugfest into a rapid-fire crit machine or a spell-amplifying powerhouse depending on what drops you encounter. The unpredictability keeps each floor exciting — even when you fail, there’s a sense that the next attempt might click just right. The game encourages experimentation by giving you frequent opportunities to rotate gear, adjust strategies, and pursue unexpected synergies that emerge mid-run. This makes climbs feel less like linear exercises and more like improvisational problem-solving under pressure.

The tower itself is crafted with a clear dark-fantasy identity. Hand-drawn 2D artistry gives each floor a distinct mood, from shadowy halls to fiery chambers to eerie, ruin-laden corridors. The environments aren’t overly detailed, but they establish a visual rhythm that helps each ascent feel like a journey through a folkloric hellscape. Enemies swarm in varied formations, bosses punctuate the climb with bursts of challenge, and the screen often fills with enough chaos to make victories genuinely thrilling. The visual clarity holds up even when dozens of enemies, spells, and animated effects converge at once — a critical quality for a game that lives or dies by its responsiveness.

Yet its Early Access nature does show through in certain areas. Despite a variety of classes and gear types, the balance between skills and basic attacks is not quite even. Some classes feel most effective when relying heavily on standard attacks, which diminishes incentive to invest deeply in skill upgrades or more complex builds. Likewise, the itemization — while generous in drops — can feel overly dependent on luck. Non-legendary gear becomes obsolete quickly, nudging players toward hunting specific rare drops instead of crafting adaptable builds. These balance issues don’t ruin the experience, but they do create occasional moments where strategy takes a backseat to the randomness of the loot pool.

The structure of the runs is fast and digestible, but also somewhat narrow in scope. With only around a dozen floors to ascend, a run never overstays its welcome, but it also doesn’t offer long-form progression or the sweeping arcs that some roguelite fans may crave. The short length works well for players who enjoy quick, repeatable bursts of action, but others may find the format limiting once they master the early floors. Still, the developers have stated their intent to expand the game with new floors, enemies, classes, and features, and the solid foundation already in place suggests the game could grow considerably with future updates.

Despite these limitations, Tower of Babel: Survivors of Chaos succeeds in delivering a high-energy, loot-driven action experience that is easy to pick up and hard to put down. Its synergy between gear randomness and fast-paced combat keeps runs dynamic, and its clear visual style reinforces the frenetic pace without confusion. For players who enjoy experimenting with builds, chasing the thrill of lucky drops, and carving through hordes of enemies on the climb to an ever-higher floor, the game offers a compelling and addictive rhythm. With more refinement and additional content, it has the potential to stand out even more prominently in the roguelite action space. Even as it is now, it’s an engaging, chaotic, and rewarding excursion up a tower where every floor tests your resolve and every run feels like a fresh chance at mastery.

I have played 5 levels and haven't died yet, but I've gotten somewhat close. This game makes me feel like I'm doing a good job making choices, but I can't say for sure what the difficulty level is. 

I know this is early access and features will be added/developed as time goes on. There are two things that I would love to be added. The first one is just a fun idea, and the second would take my recommendation from "Buy if its on sale" to "I plan to buy this for my friends!"

1. There is the option to increase the difficulty for a floor. This seems to be based on lowering resistances and rewards you with increasing the drop rate. I would be interested in a fast forward option (hyper mode or something like that) that moves the game clock faster as well as making the character attack/walk faster and enemies spawn/attack/walk faster. Would allow me to tackle an easier level quickly when I don't have as much time to commit to the game. Would be harder to control so could potentially provide risk/reward opportunities for grinding gear.

2. Multiplayer, please? I know not everything has to be a multiplayer, but at this stage in my life I just want to spend time with my wife and family when I'm unwinding at the end of the day. A game like this is way more relaxing/engaging (oxymoron? oh well, I want both) that just putting a show on the TV. But except for the days when my people are busy, it's hard to choose a single player game when I could choose one where I also get to spend time with them. I'm playing this game right now because it's new, but when the shine wears off, multiplayer would keep me coming back regularly and bringing my people with me. Especially if I can run split-screen and sit on the couch next to my wife while we play instead of across the room.

Fix the item UI.
Make the skills gradually unlock (for the New Player Experience).
